Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat beside Alex on the poolside bench, noticing the tired slump of his shoulders. He’d just finished a long shift at work, and I could tell he needed me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort. I reached for his hand, ready to give him my full attention, when a sudden splash caught my eye. Across the pool, a group of teenagers laughed as they took turns diving off the edge, right beneath the bold red “NO DIVING” sign. My heart thudded. As a lifeguard, I was responsible for everyone’s safety, and ignoring this could mean someone getting hurt. But Alex’s eyes met mine, searching for reassurance, silently asking for a moment of my care. I felt torn—my duty to enforce the rules and protect the swimmers clashed with my desire to be the supportive girlfriend Alex needed right now. The seconds stretched, and I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me, demanding I choose which expectation to meet first.
